description: German invasion of Poland
Nepal declares war on Germany.
The United States declares its neutrality in the war.
South Africa declares war on Germany.

Forward elements of General Hoeppner's XVI Panzerkorps take up positions outside Warsaw. The world is stunned by the rapidity of the German advance and the Polish High Command is effectively isolated, but lack of infantry support and effective civilian resistance cause Hoeppner to halt outside the city itself.

Polish troops on the Westerplatte are forced, due to lack of food and ammunition, to surrender. The garrison of about two hundred had held out against thousands of German forces (many of them Naval officer cadets from the ''Schleswig-Holstein,'') for seven days.

Troops of the Polish Poznan Army under the command of General Kutrzeba open the Battle of the Bzura, the largest and best organized counter-attack mounted by the Polish forces in the campaign of 1939. For the first few days all goes well and the Germans are forced to retreat but quick reaction by mechanized units and the Luftwaffe soon take their toll and the operation bogs down.
Canada declares war on Germany.
Diverse elements of the German Wehrmacht surround Warsaw and demand its surrender. The Poles refuse and the siege begins in earnest.
The Soviet Union invades Poland and then occupies eastern Polish territories.
The Poznan pocket collapses, and the Germans capture, according to many sources, over 150,000 men. Many elements of General Kutrzeba's forces work their way into Warsaw under extreme difficulty.
Joint victory parade of Wehrmacht and Red Army in Brest-Litovsk at the end of the Invasion of Poland.
Germany annexes Western Poland.
Physicist Hans Ferdinand Mayer writes the Oslo Report on German weapons systems and passes it to the British Secret Intelligence Service.
U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt orders the United States Customs Service to implement the Neutrality Act of 1939, allowing cash-and-carry purchases of weapons to non-belligerent nations.
Sonderaktion Krakau: Germans take action against scientists from the University of Kraków and other Kraków universities at the beginning of WWII.
In Munich, an attempt to kill Adolf Hitler is made by Georg Elser while Hitler is celebrating the 16th anniversary of the Beer Hall Putsch.
Venlo Incident: Two British agents of SIS are captured by the Germans.
To punish protests against the Nazi occupation of the Czech homeland, the Nazis murder 9 Czech graduate students, send over 1200 to concentration camps, and close all Czech universities.
Winter War: Soviet forces attack Finland and reach the Mannerheim Line, starting the war.
Sweden declares non-belligerency in the Winter War.
''HMS Nelson'' is struck by a mine (laid by U-31) off the Scottish coast and is laid up for repairs until August 1940.
''HMS Duchess'' sinks after a collision with ''HMS Barham'' off the coast of Scotland with the loss of 124 men.

Battle of the River Plate:  The German pocket battleship, ''Admiral Graf Spee'' is trapped by cruisers HMS ''Ajax'', HMNZS ''Achilles'', and HMS ''Exeter'' after a running battle off the coast of Uruguay. ''Admiral Graf Spee'' is scuttled by its crew off Montevideo harbor on December 17.
Winter War: The League of Nations expels the USSR for attacking Finland.
Axis powers: Luftwaffe General Hermann Göring assumes control of most war industries in Germany.
Winter War: General Semyon Timoshenko takes command of all Russian forces.
Winter War: Battle of Suomussalmi: The Russian 44th Assault Division is destroyed by Finnish forces.
Food rationing begins in Great Britain.
WWII British submarine HMS Starfish 19S is sunk.
Mechelen Incident: A German plane carrying secret plans for the invasion of western Europe makes a forced landing in Belgium, leading to mobilization of defense forces in the Low Countries.
A peace resolution introduced in the Parliament of South Africa is defeated 81–59.
Winter War: Russian forces launch a major assault on Finnish troops occupying the Karelian Isthmus.
Altmark Incident: The British destroyer HMS Cossack F03 pursues the German tanker ''Altmark'' into Jøssingfjord in southwestern Norway.
Axis powers: Adolf Hitler and Benito Mussolini meet at Brenner Pass in the Alps and agree to form an alliance against France and the United Kingdom.
Commerce raiding Ship German auxiliary cruiser Atlantis, leaves the Wadden Sea for what will become the longest warship cruise of the war. (622 days without in-port replenishment or repair)
Operation ''Weserübung'': German ships set out for the invasion of Norway.
Germany invades Denmark and Norway in Operation ''Weserübung.'' The British campaign in Norway is simultaneously commenced.
German armies open a 60 km wide breach in the Maginot Line at Sedan, France.
The Dutch army surrenders.
German forces (2nd Panzer division), under General Rudolf Veiel, reach Noyelles on the English Channel.
The British Parliament passes a further Emergency Powers (Defence) Act, giving the government full control over all persons and property.
The Anglo-French Supreme War Council decides to withdraw all forces from Norway.
The Dunkirk evacuation of the British Expeditionary Force starts.
King Leopold III of Belgium orders the Belgian forces to cease fighting. Leaders of the Belgian government on French territory declare Leopold deposed.
The Vought XF4U-1, prototype of the F4U Corsair U.S. fighter later used in WWII, makes its first flight.
Paris is bombed by the Luftwaffe for the first time.
The Dunkirk evacuation ends: British and Dutch forces complete evacuating 300,000 troops from Dunkirk in France to England.

Winston Churchill tells the British House of Commons, ampquotWe shall not flag or fail. We shall fight on the beaches... on the landing grounds... in the fields and the streets.... We shall never surrender.ampquot

link.text_in_event: We Shall Fight on the Beaches

description: The British Commandos are created.
Italy declares war on France and the United Kingdom.
U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt denounces Italy's actions with his 'Stab in the Back' speech during the graduation ceremonies of the University of Virginia.
Canada declares war on Italy.
Norway surrenders to German forces.
The French government flees to Tours.
13,000 British and French troops surrender to Field Marshal Erwin Rommel at St. Valery-en-Caux.
Paris is declared an open city.
The Soviet Union annexes three Baltic States which are Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania. This is the most popular date to be said when the term Soviet Empire was coined.
The French government flees to Bordeaux and Paris falls under German occupation.
U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt signs the Naval Expansion Act into law, which aims to increase the United States Navy's tonnage by 11%.
A group of 728 Polish political prisoners from Tarnów become the first residents of the Auschwitz concentration camp.
Verdun falls to German forces.
Operation Ariel begins: Allied troops start to evacuate France, following Germany's takeover of Paris and most of the nation.
A Luftwaffe Junkers 88 bomber sinks the British ship ''RMS Lancastria'', which was evacuating troops from near Saint-Nazaire, France, killing some 5,800 men.
Winston Churchill says to the House of Commons: ampquotThe Battle of France is over. The Battle of Britain is about to begin.ampquot

Appeal of 18 June: General Charles de Gaulle, ''de facto'' leader of the Free French Forces, makes his first broadcast appeal over Radio Londres from London rallying French Resistance, calling on all French people to continue the fight against Nazi Germany: ampquotFrance has lost a battle. But France has not lost the warampquot.
Vichy France and Germany sign an armistice at Compiegne, in the same wagon-lit railroad car used by Marshal Ferdinand Foch to accept the surrender of Germany in 1918.
German leader Adolf Hitler surveys newly defeated Paris in now occupied France.
Vichy France signs armistice terms with Italy.
German forces land in Guernsey, marking the start of the 5-year Occupation of the Channel Islands.

British-owned SS Arandora Star, carrying civilian internees and POWs of Italian and German origin from Liverpool to Canada, is torpedoed and sunk by the GS U-47 1938 6 off northwest Ireland with the loss of around 865 lives.
British naval units sink or seize ships of the French fleet anchored in the Algerian ports of Oran and Mers-el-Kebir. The following day, Vichy France breaks off diplomatic relations with Britain
The Battle of Britain begins
British destroyer HMS Escort H66 is torpedoed and sunk by an Italian submarine.
Vichy France begins with a constitutional law which only 80 members of the parliament vote against.

Winston Churchill, in a worldwide broadcast, proclaims the intention of Great Britain to fight alone against Germany whatever the outcome: quotWe shall seek no terms. We shall tolerate no parley. We may show mercy. We shall ask none.quot
Allied victory at the Battle of Cape Spada HMAS Sydney D48 and five destroyers sink the Italian cruiser ''Bartolomeo Colleoni''.
Adolf Hitler makes a peace appeal to Britain in an address to the Reichstag. Lord Halifax, the British foreign minister, flatly rejects peace terms in a broadcast reply on July 22.
British submarine HMS Spearfish 69S is sunk.
Wilhelm Keitel signs the quotAufbau Ostquot directive, which eventually leads to the invasion of the Soviet Union.
British armed merchant cruiser HMS Transylvania F56 is torpedoed off Malin Head, Ireland, by German submarine ''U-56''.
Winston Churchill pays tribute in the House of Commons to the Royal Air Force: ampquotNever in the field of human conflict was so much owed by so many to so few.ampquot

link.text_in_event: so much owed by so many to so few

description: Chad is the first French colony to proclaim its support for the Allies.

September: The U.S. Army 45th Infantry Division (previously a National Guard Division in Arizona, Colorado, New Mexico, and Oklahoma), is activated and ordered into federal service for 1 year, to engage in a training program in Ft. Sill and Louisiana, prior to serving in WWII.

An agreement between America and Great Britain is announced to the effect that 50 U.S. destroyers needed for escort work will be transferred to Great Britain. In return, America gains 99-year leases on British bases in the North Atlantic, West Indies and Bermuda.

Commerce raiding German auxiliary cruiser ''Komet'' enters the Pacific Ocean via the Bering Strait after crossing the Arctic Ocean from the North Sea with the help of Soviet icebreakers ''Lenin'', ''Stalin'', and ''Kaganovich''.
The Blitz: Nazi Germany begins to rain bombs on London (the first of 57 consecutive nights of strategic bombing).
The Selective Training and Service Act of 1940 is signed into law by Franklin D. Roosevelt, creating the first peacetime draft in U.S. history.

link.text_in_event: Selective Training and Service Act of 1940

description: September 18: SS City of Benares is torpedoed by GS U-48 1939 6 in the Atlantic with the loss of 248 of the 406 on board, including child evacuees bound for Canada. This results in cancellation of the British Children's Overseas Reception Board's plan to relocate children overseas.
The United States imposes a total embargo on all scrap metal shipments to Japan.
Germany, Italy and Japan sign the Tripartite Pact.
October 19: Thirty-two ships are sunk from Convoy SC 7 and Convoy HX 79 by the most effective quotwolfpackquot of the war including U-boat aces Kretschmer, Prien and Schepke
Italian troops invade Greece, meeting strong resistance from Greek troops and civilians. This action signals the beginning of the Balkans Campaign.
The Royal Navy launches the first aircraft carrier strike in history, on the Italian battleship fleet anchored at Taranto naval base.
Ship German auxiliary cruiser Atlantis captures top secret British mail, and sends it to Japan.

The city of Coventry, England is destroyed by 500 Luftwaffe bombers: 150,000 fire bombs, 503 tons of high explosives, and 130 parachute mines level 60,000 of the city's 75,000 buildings 568 people are killed.
In response to Germany levelling Coventry 2 days before, the Royal Air Force begins to bomb Hamburg (by war's end, 50,000 Hamburg residents will have died from Allied attacks).
German leader Adolf Hitler and Italian Foreign Minister Galeazzo Ciano meet to discuss Benito Mussolini's disastrous invasion of Greece.
Hungary, Romania and Slovakia join the Axis Powers.
The Royal Navy and Regia Marina fight the Battle of Cape Spartivento.
Operation Compass: British forces in North Africa begin their first major offensive with an attack on Italian forces at Sidi Barrani, Egypt.
nd December 15: quotSheffield Blitzquot: The Yorkshire city of Sheffield is badly damaged by German air-raids.
WWII British destroyers HMS Hereward H93 and HMS Hyperion H97 sink an Italian submarine off Bardia.
Operation Abigail Rachel: RAF bombing of Mannheim.

Winston Churchill, in a broadcast address to the people of Italy, blames Benito Mussolini for leading his nation to war against the British, contrary to Italy's historic friendship with them: quotOne man has arrayed the trustees and inheritors of ancient Rome upon the side of the ferocious pagan barbarians.quot

ampquotSecond Great Fire of Londonampquot: Luftwaffe carries out a massive incendiary bombing raid, starting 1,500 fires. Many famous buildings, including the Guildhall and Trinity House, are either damaged or destroyed.
Olympic Games, assigned to Tokyo, Japan, and later to Helsinki, Finland, are suspended due to WWII.
At the Battle of Bardia in Libya, Australian and British troops defeat Italian forces, the first battle of the war in which an Australian Army formation takes part.
Commerce raiding ''hilfskreuzer Pinguin'' captures the Norwegian whaling fleet near Bouvet Island, effectively ending Southern Ocean whaling for the duration of the war.
British troops attack Italian-held Eritrea.
Battle of Tobruk: Australian and British forces capture Tobruk from the Italians.
Attack on Pearl Harbor:  Joseph C. Grew, the U.S. ambassador to Japan, reports to Washington a rumor overheard at a diplomatic reception concerning a planned surprise attack on Pearl Harbor, Hawaii.
Australians capture Derna, Libya from the Italians.
The Nazis forcibly restore Pierre Laval to office in occupied Vichy France.
The United Service Organization (USO) is created to entertain American troops.
Fall of Benghazi to the Western Desert Force. Lieutenant-General Erwin Rommel is appointed commander of Afrika Korps.
The U.S. House of Representatives passes the Lend-Lease Act (260–165).
Erwin Rommel arrives in Tripoli.
Admiral Kichisaburo Nomura begins his duties as Japanese Ambassador to the United States.

February 22: Three Nights' Blitz over Swansea, South Wales: Over these 3 nights of intensive bombing, which last a total of 13 hours and 48 minutes, Swansea's town centre is almost completely obliterated by the 896 high explosive bombs employed by the Luftwaffe. A total of 397 casualties and 230 deaths are reported.
Bulgaria signs the Tripartite Pact, thus joining the Axis powers.
Operation Claymore - British Commandos carry out a successful raid on the Lofoten Islands off the north coast of Norway.
The U.S. Senate passes the Lend-Lease Act (60–31).
President Franklin Delano Roosevelt signs the Lend-Lease Act into law.
Rommel launches his first offensive in Cyrenaica.
The Kingdom of Yugoslavia joins the Axis powers in Vienna.
Axis forces capture Benghazi.
Germany invades Yugoslavia and Greece.

The U.S. destroyer USS Niblack DD-424 6, while picking up survivors from a sunken Dutch freighter, drops depth charges on a German U-Boat (the first quotshot in angerquot fired by America against Germany).citation needed date=May 2010 reason=there's doubt it was actually a sub
German troops enter Belgrade.
Axis forces reach Halfaya Pass on the Libyan-Egyptian frontier.
The Yugoslav Royal Army capitulates.
Prime Minister of Greece Alexandros Koryzis commits suicide as German troops approach Athens.
Greece capitulates. Commonwealth troops and some elements of the Greek Army withdraw to Crete.
German troops enter Athens.
Emperor Haile Selassie enters Addis Ababa, which had been liberated from Italian forces this date has been since commemorated as Liberation Day in Ethiopia.
The German auxiliary cruiser Pinguin is sunk by HMS Cornwall (56) in the Indian Ocean.
The German submarine ''U-110'' is captured by the British Royal Navy. On board is the latest Enigma cryptography machine, which Allied cryptographers later use to break coded German messages.
The British House of Commons is damaged by the Luftwaffe in an air raid.
The Battle of Crete begins as Germany launches an airborne invasion of Crete.
In the North Atlantic, the German battleship ''Bismarck'' sinks battlecruiser HMS ''Hood'', killing all but 3 crewmen from a total of 1,418 aboard the pride of the Royal Navy.
In the North Atlantic, Fairey Swordfish aircraft from the carrier HMS ''Ark Royal'' cripple the steering of ''Bismarck'' in an aerial torpedo attack.
President Roosevelt proclaims an ampquotunlimited national emergency.ampquot
WWII:''Bismarck'' is sunk in the North Atlantic, killing 2,300.
Manolis Glezos and Apostolos Santas tear down the Nazi swastika on the Acropolis in Athens, and replace it with the Greek flag
British and Free French forces invade Syria.
Royal Navy planes sink the  Vichy French ship Chevalier Paul
Italy and Romania declare war on the Soviet Union.
Germany invades the Soviet Union under Operation Barbarossa.

Winston Churchill promises all possible British assistance to the Soviet Union in a worldwide broadcast:  ampquotAny man or state who fights against Nazidom will have our aid.  Any man or state who marches with Hitler is our foe.ampquot
The First Sisak Partisan Brigade, the first anti-fascist armed unit in occupied Europe, is founded by partisans near Sisak, Croatia.
Hungary and Slovakia declare war on the Soviet Union.
Finland attacks the Soviet Union to seek the opportunity of revenge in the Continuation War.
Albania declares war on the Soviet Union.
Empire of Japan calls up 1 million men for military service.
Joseph Stalin, in his first address since the German invasion, calls upon the Soviet people to carry out a quotscorched earthquot policy of resistance to the bitter end.
German troops reach the Dnieper River.
American forces take over the defense of Iceland from the British.
German troops take over Estonia from the Soviets.

Montenegro starts the second popular uprising in Europe against the Axis Powers, the first being the so-called February strike against deportation of Jews in Amsterdam and surroundings on February 25, 1941.
Vichy France signs armistice terms, ending all fighting in Syria and Lebanon.
A BBC broadcast by ampquotColonel Brittonampquot calls on the people of occupied Europe to resist the Nazis under the slogan ampquotV for Victoryampquot.
WWII Italian planes damege the destroyer HMS Fearless (H67) which has to be sunk by the British.
In response to the Japanese occupation of French Indo-China, U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt orders the seizure of all Japanese assets in the United States.
General Douglas MacArthur is named commander of all U.S. forces in the Philippines the Philippines Army is ordered nationalized by President Roosevelt.

The Holocaust: Under instructions from Adolf Hitler, Nazi official Hermann Göring orders S.S. General Reinhard Heydrich to quotsubmit to me as soon as possible a general plan of the administrative material and financial measures necessary for carrying out the desired Final Solution of the Jewish question.quot
France: The German Occupation Authority announces that anyone found either working for or aiding the Free French will be sentenced to death.
A Luftwaffe bomb hits an Estonian steamer with 3,500 Soviet-mobilized Estonian men on board, killing 598 of them.
Operation Countenance begins with United Kingdom and Soviet forces invading Iran.
Pierre Laval is shot in an assassination attempt at Versailles, France.
The Soviets announce the destruction of the massive Dnieper River dam at Zaporozhye, to prevent its capture by the Germans.
The Siege of Leningrad begins: German forces begin a siege against the Soviet Union's second-largest city, Leningrad. Stalin orders the Volga Germans deported to Siberia.

Charles Lindbergh, at an America First Committee rally in Des Moines, Iowa, accuses quotthe British, the Jewish, and the Roosevelt administrationquot of leading the United States toward war. Widespread condemnation of Lindbergh follows.
The first snowfall is reported on the Russian front.
The Moscow Conference begins U.S. representative  Averill Harriman and British representative Lord Beaverbrook meet with Soviet foreign minister Molotov to arrange urgent assistance for Russia.
Operation Typhoon begins as Germany launches an all-out offensive against Moscow.
In their invasion of the Soviet Union, Germany reaches the Sea of Azov with the capture of Mariupol.
The Soviet Union government moves to Kuibyshev (modern Samara), but Joseph Stalin remains in Moscow.
The destroyer USS Kearny DD-432 6 is torpedoed and damaged near Iceland, killing 11 sailors (the first American military casualties of the war).
The Germans rampage in Yugoslavia, killing thousands of civilians.
Franklin Delano Roosevelt approves US$1 billion in Lend-Lease aid to the Soviet Union.
The destroyer USS ''Reuben James'' is torpedoed by a German U-boat near Iceland, killing more than 100 United States Navy sailors.

Soviet leader Joseph Stalin addresses the Soviet Union for only the second time during his three-decade rule (the first time was earlier that year on July 2). He states that even though 350,000 troops have been killed in German attacks so far, that the Germans have lost 4.5 million soldiers (a gross exaggeration) and that Soviet victory is near.

The Soviet hospital Ship Armenia is sunk by German planes while evacuating refugees, wounded military and the staff of several Crimean hospitals. It is estimated that over 5,000 people die in the sinking.
As Battle of Moscow begins, temperatures around Moscow drop to -12 °C, and the Soviet Union launches ski troops for the first time against the freezing German forces near the city.
The aircraft carrier HMS ''Ark Royal'' sinks after being torpedoed by ''U-81''.
Attack on Pearl Harbor: Joseph Grew, the United States ambassador to Japan, cables to Washington a warning that Japan may strike suddenly and unexpectedly.
Operation Crusader in North Africa begins

Both commerce raiding ''hilfskreuzer Kormoran'' and Australian cruiser HMAS ''Sydney'' sink following a battle off the coast of Western Australia.  There are no survivors from the 645 Australian sailors aboard ''Sydney''.
HMS ''Devonshire'' sinks commerce raiding ''hilfskreuzer Atlantis'', ending the longest warship cruise of the war. (622 days without in-port replenishment or repair)
Attack on Pearl Harbor: A fleet of 6 aircraft carriers commanded by Japanese Vice Admiral Chuichi Nagumo leaves Hitokapu Bay for Pearl Harbor under strict radio silence
Germans reach their closest approach to Moscow. They are subsequently frozen by cold weather and attacks by the Soviets.

Attack on Pearl Harbor: The code message quotClimb Mount Niitakaquot is transmitted to the Japanese task force, indicating that negotiations have broken down and that the attack is to be carried out according to plan.
HMS Perseus (N36)is sunk by a mine.
December 8, Japan standard time): WWII:
The United States, United Kingdom, China and The Netherlands officially declare war on the Empire of Japan.
The British battleship HMS ''Prince of Wales'' and battlecruiser HMS ''Repulse'' are sunk by Japanese aircraft in the South China Sea north of Singapore.
Germany and Italy declare war on the United States. The U.S. responds in kind.
Hitler becomes Supreme Commander-in-Chief of the German Army.
A second Japanese landing attempt on Wake Island is successful, and the American garrison surrenders after a full night and morning of fighting.
The British and Canadians are defeated by the Japanese at Hong Kong.
Winston Churchill becomes the first British Prime Minister to address a joint session of the U.S. Congress.

link.text_in_event: joint session of the U.S. Congress

description: British Commandos raid the Norwegian port of Vaagso, causing Hitler to reinforce the garrison and defenses, drawing vital troops away from other areas.
United States and Philippines troops fight the Battle of Bataan.
Manila is captured by Japanese forces. All defending soldiers in Manila are killed.
The siege of the Bataan Peninsula begins.

The last German air-raid on Liverpool destroys the home of William Patrick Hitler, Adolf Hitler's nephew. William Hitler is at this time in the United States where he later joins the navy to fight against his uncle.
Erwin Rommel launches his new offensive in Cyrenaica.
The Battle of Rabaul begins.
Thailand declares war on the United States and United Kingdom.
The first American forces arrive in Europe, landing in Northern Ireland.
Battle of Malaya: The last organized Allied forces leave British Malaya, ending the 54-day campaign.
The Command staff of the Eighth Air Force reaches England!-- becomes active in the European Theater of Operations, but won't fly missions until July 4th, 1942 using borrowed British planes.
President Franklin Delano Roosevelt signs an executive order directing the internment of Japanese Americans and the seizure of their property.
Rommel suspends his offensive in Cyrenaica.
Top United States military leaders hold their first formal meeting to discuss American military strategy in the war.
The ocean liner SS Normandie catches fire while being converted into the troopship USS ''Lafayette'' (AP-53) for WWII.
Singapore surrenders to Japanese forces.
Lieutenant Edward O'Hare becomes America's first U.S. Navy WWII flying ace.

The SS Struma, carrying Jewish refugees from Axis-allied Romania to British-controlled Palestine, is torpedoed and sunk by the Soviet submarine ''Shch 213'', killing 768 men, women and children, with only one survivor, a 19 year old man, making it the largest exclusively civilian naval disaster of the war.The actual number of victims, including the ten person crew, is uncertain, although a recent study concludes it may have been as high as 791, of which 785 were Jewish. Franz Collins' book ''Death on the Black Sea: The Untold Story of the Struma and WWII's Holocaust at Sea'', calls it simply the quotlargest naval civilian disaster of the war.quot (page 255)

Battle of the Java Sea: An allied (ABDA) task force of 14 vessels under Dutch command, trying to stem a  Japanese invasion of the Dutch East Indies, is defeated by a 19 vessel Japanese task force in the Java Sea 2.300 sailors die, including the commander, admiral Karel Doorman Japanese attain naval hegemony in East-Asia
March: Construction begins on the Badger Army Ammunition Plant (the largest in the United States during WWII).

Executive order 9082 (February 28, 1942) reorganizes the United States Army into three major commands: Army Ground Forces, Army Air Forces, and Services of Supply, later redesignated Army Service Forces.

March 12: General General Douglas MacArthur, his family, and key members of his staff are evacuated by PT boat, under cover of darkness, from Corregidor in the Philippines. Command of US forces in the Philippines passes to Major General Jonathan M. Wainwright.
New Zealand and Australia declared war on Thailand.
The Germans burned down the Ukrainian village of Yelino (Koriukivka Raion), killing 296 civilians.
Operation Chariot - British Commandos raid St. Nazaire on the coast of Western France.
Japanese forces begin an all-out assault on the United States and Filipino troops on the Bataan Peninsula.
the Japanese Navy attacks Colombo in Ceylon (Sri Lanka). Royal Navy Cruisers HMS Cornwall 56 and HMS Dorsetshire 40 are sunk southwest of the island.
The submarine HMS Upholder P37 is sunk.
The German submarine U-85 (1941) is sunk by USS Roper DD-147.

King George VI awards the George Cross to Malta to mark the Siege of Malta, saying, quotTo honour her brave people I award the George Cross to the Island Fortress of Malta, to bear witness to a heroism and a devotion that will long be famous in history (from January 1 to July 24, there is only one 24-hour period during which no bombs fall on this tiny island).quot
Henri Giraud the French commander captured in 1940, escapes from  Königstein Fortress.
Tokyo, Japan, is attacked by the Doolittle Raid, a small force of B-25 Mitchell bomber aircraft commanded by then-Lieutenant Colonel James Doolittle.

The Reichstag meets for the last time, dissolving itself and proclaiming Adolf Hitler the quotSupreme Judge of the German Peoplequot, granting him the power of life and death over every German citizen.
A national plebiscite is held in Canada on the issue of conscription.
An explosion at a chemical factory in Tessenderlo, Belgium leaves 200 dead and 1,000 injured.
Operation Ironclad: United Kingdom forces invade the French colony of Madagascar.
On Corregidor, the last American and Filipino forces in the Philippines surrender to the Japanese.
The Battle of the Coral Sea (first battle in naval history where 2 enemy fleets fight without seeing each other's fleets) ends in an Allied victory.

May 9: At night, gunners of the Ceylon Garrison Artillery on Horsburgh Island in the Cocos Islands rebel. Their mutiny is crushed and 3 of them executed (the only British Commonwealth soldiers to be executed for mutiny during the Second World War).

Second Battle of Kharkov: In the eastern Ukraine, the Soviet Army initiates a major offensive. During the battle the Soviets capture the city of Kharkov from the German Army, only to be encircled and destroyed.
WWII The Japanese minelayer Okinoshima is sunk by the American submarine USS S-42 (SS-153).
In the United States, a bill creating the Women's Auxiliary Army Corps (WAAC) is signed into law.
Mexico declares war against Nazi Germany after the sinking of the Mexican tanker ''Faja de Oro'' by the German U-boat, U-160, off Key West.
Battle of Bir Hakeim: The Free French and British troops slow the German advance in North Africa.

WWII Anglo-Soviet Treaty of 1942 to help establish military and political alliance between the USSR and the British Empire  is signed in London by foreign Secretary Anthony Eden and by Soviet foreign minister Vyacheslav Molotov.
Operation Anthropoid: Czech paratroopers attempt to assassinate Reinhard Heydrich in Prague.
June 1: Attack on Sydney Harbour: Japanese submarines infiltrate Sydney Harbour in an attempt to attack Allied warships.
Mexico declares war on Germany, Italy and Japan.
Reinhard Heydrich succumbs to wounds sustained on May 27 from Czechoslovakian paratroopers acting in Operation Anthropoid.
June 7: The Battle of Midway: The Japanese naval advance in the Pacific is halted.
Japanese forces invade the Aleutian Islands (the first invasion of American soil in 128 years).
Attack on Sydney Harbour: The Australian cities of Sydney and Newcastle are shelled by Japanese submarines. The eastern suburbs of both cities are damaged and the east coast is blacked out.
The Gestapo massacres 173 male residents of Lidice, Czechoslovakia in retaliation for the killing of Reinhard Heydrich.
The United States opens its Office of War Information, a propaganda center.
The German Eleventh Army under Erich von Manstein takes Sevastopol, although fighting rages until July 9.
July 27: The First Battle of El Alamein.
Guadalcanal, occupied only by aborigines falls to the Japanese Naval construction force deployed to construct an air field on the island.
WWII in the European Theater of Operations:
German U-Boats sink 3 more merchant ships in the Gulf of St. Lawrence.
Germany introduces the Ostvolk Medal for Soviet personnel in the Wehrmacht.
The Germans test fly the Messerschmitt Me 262 (using only its jets) for the first time.
Battle of the Atlantic: German Grand Admiral Karl Dönitz orders the last U-boats to withdraw from their United States Atlantic coast positions, in response to an effective American convoy system.
Battle of Guadalcanal begins: The U.S. Navy and the U.S. Marine Corps begin the first American offensive of the war with an amphibious landing on the island of Guadalcanal in the Solomon Islands.

In Washington, DC, six Germans would-be saboteurs are executed. (Two others are cooperative and receive sentences of life imprisonment instead one is spared because of his relatively young age. Those imprisoned are freed a few years after the end of the war.)
The American tanker SS ''Ohio'' reaches Malta as part of the convoy of ''Operation Pedestal''.
First raid by heavy bombers of U.S. Eighth Air Force against occupied France.
Dieppe Raid: Allied forces raid Dieppe, France.
Brazil declares war on Germany and Italy.
German troops reach the suburbs of Stalingrad.
Japanese marines land at Milne Bay.
September 5: Battle of Alam Halfa.
A German attempt to liquidate the Jewish ghetto in Lakhva leads to an uprising.
Battle of Milne Bay: Japanese forces suffer their first defeat on land.
A Japanese floatplane drops incendiary devices at Mount Emily, near Brookings, Oregon, in the first of two quotLookout Air Raidsquot, the first bombing of the continental United States.

Both commerce raiding ''hilfskreuzer Stier'' and Liberty ship ''Stephen Hopkins'' sink following a gun battle in the South Atlantic. ''Stier'' is the only commerce raider to be sunk by Defensively Equipped Merchant Ships.
Battle of Cape Esperance: On the northwest coast of Guadalcanal, United States Navy ships intercept and defeat a Japanese fleet on their way to reinforce troops on the island.
November 4: Second Battle of El Alamein: British troops go on the offensive against the Axis forces.
Battle of the Santa Cruz Islands: Two Japanese aircraft carriers are heavily damaged and one U.S.N. carrier is sunk.

link.text_in_event: Battle of the Santa Cruz Islands

description: Second Battle of El Alamein: German forces under Erwin Rommel are forced to retreat during the night.
U.S serviceman Edward Leonski is hanged at Melbourne's Pentridge Prison for the quotBrown-Outquot murders of 3 women in May.
In violation of a 1940 armistice, Germany invades Vichy France, following French Admiral François Darlan's agreement to an armistice with the Allies in North Africa.
Battle of Guadalcanal: A naval battle near Guadalcanal starts between Japanese and American forces.
Battle of Stalingrad: Soviet Union forces under General Georgy Zhukov launch the Operation Uranus counter-attacks at Stalingrad, turning the tide of the battle in the USSR's favor.
British forces capture Benghazi.

Battle of Stalingrad: The situation for the German attackers of Stalingrad seems desperate during the Soviet counter-attack Operation Uranus, and General Friedrich Paulus sends Adolf Hitler a telegram saying that the German Sixth Army is surrounded.

A German U-boat sinks the SS ''Ben Lomond'' off the coast of Brazil. One crewman, Chinese second steward Poon Lim, is separated from the others and spends 130 days adrift until he is rescued on April 3, 1943.
26: Operation Harling: A British SOE team, together with Greek Resistance fighters, blows up the Gorgopotamos viaduct in the first major sabotage act in occupied continental Europe.
At Toulon, the French navy scuttles its ships and submarines to keep them out of Nazi hands.
USAAF bombers make their first raid on Italy.
British commandos conduct Operation Frankton, a raid on shipping in Bordeaux harbour.
The Japanese are driven off Guadalcanal.
Soviet officials announce they have broken the Wehrmacht's siege of Leningrad.
British forces capture Tripoli from the Italians.
50 bombers mount the first all American air raid against Germany (Wilhelmshaven is the target).
In Russia, the Battle of Stalingrad comes to an end with the surrender of the German 6th Army.
The Four Chaplains of the U.S. Army are drowned, when their ship (USAT Dorchester) is struck by a German torpedo.
In the United States, it is announced that shoe rationing will go into effect in 2 days.
Battle of Guadalcanal: United States forces defeat Japanese troops.
The Soviet Union reconquers Kharkov, but is later driven out in the Third Battle of Kharkov
March 1–2: Koriukivka massacre takes place in Ukraine.
Battle of the Bismarck Sea: United States and Australian forces sink Japanese convoy ships.
American forces are attacked by Japanese troops on Hill 700 in Bougainville, in a battle that will last 5 days.
On Bougainville, Japanese troops end their assault on American forces at Hill 700.
British submarine HMS ''Thunderbolt'' sunk off Sicily by an Italian corvette, the second time this vessel has been lost with all hands.
March 19:  22 ships from Convoys HX 229/SC 122 and one U-boat are sunk in the largest North Atlantic U-boat wolfpack attack of the war.
The entire population of Khatyn in Belarus is burnt alive by the German occupation forces.
Battle of the Komandorski Islands: In the Aleutian Islands, the battle begins when United States Navy forces intercept Japanese troops attempting to reinforce a garrison at Kiska.
Escort carrier ''Dasher'' was destroyed by an accidental explosion in the Firth of Clyde, killing 379 of the crew of 528.
Radio Berlin announces the discovery by Wehrmacht of mass graves of Poles killed by Soviets in the Katyn massacre.
Six U-boats are sunk after sinking 12 ships from Convoy ONS 5 in the last major North Atlantic U-boat quotwolfpackquot attack of the war.
American troops invade Attu in the Aleutian Islands, in an attempt to expel occupying Japanese forces.
German Afrika Korps and Italian troops in North Africa surrender to Allied forces.
Operation Chastise by RAF 617 Sqdn are carried out on German dams.
Japanese battleship Mutsu was destroyed by an accidental magazine explosion in Hashirajima anchorage, killing 1,121.
Americans and Japanese fight the Battle of Kula Gulf off Kolombangara.

Allied invasion of Sicily: The allied invasion of Axis-controlled Europe begins with landings on the island of Sicily off mainland Italy, by the Seventh United States Army and the British Eighth Army including the 1st Canadian Infantry Division.
Battle of Prokhorovka: The Wehrmacht and the Red Army fight to a draw.
The invasion of Sicily begins with British landings at Augusta on the island's eastern side and American landings to the south.
Rome is bombed by the Allies for the first time in the war.

Operation Gomorrha begins: British and Canadian aeroplanes bomb Hamburg by night the American planes bomb the city by day. By the end of the operation in November, 9,000 tons of explosives will have killed more than 30,000 people and destroyed 280,000 buildings.
Operation Gomorrha: The British bomb Hamburg, causing a firestorm that kills 42,000 German civilians.
John F. Kennedy's PT-109 is rammed by a destroyer.
The ''USS Intrepid (CV-11)'' is launched.
John F. Kennedy and crew are found by Solomon Islanders coastwatchers Biuku Gasa and Eroni Kumana with their dugout canoe.
Battle of Vella Gulf: Americans defeat a Japanese convoy off Kolombangara, as the U.S. Army drives the Japanese out of Munda airfield on New Georgia.
Rome is declared an open city.
The US 7th Army under General George S. Patton meets the British 8th Army under Field Marshal Bernard L. Montgomery in Messina, Sicily, completing the Allied conquest of Sicily.
WWII:: Heinrich Himmler is named Reichminister of the Interior in Germany .
Lord Louis Mountbatten is named Supreme Allied Commander for Southeast Asia.
King Boris III of Bulgaria dies under peculiar circumstances his 6-year-old son, Simeon II, ascends to the throne.
Germany dissolves the Danish government after it refuses to deal with a wave of strikes and disturbances to the satisfaction of the German authorities (see Occupation of Denmark).
Mainland Italy is invaded by Allied forces under Bernard L. Montgomery, for the first time in the war.
The 503rd Parachute Regiment under American General Douglas MacArthur lands and occupies Nadzab, just east of the port city of Lae in northeastern Papua New Guinea.
German paratroopers rescue Mussolini from imprisonment, in quotOperation Oakquot.
The Salerno Mutiny occurs within the British X Corps.
The Villefranche-de-Rouergue uprising takes place.
The Republic of Salò is founded.
The 4-day Naples Uprising begins.
American forces enter liberated Naples.
Americans and Japanese fight the naval Battle of Vella Lavella.
The Naples post office explosion kills 100.
The new government of Italy sides with the Allies and declares war on Germany.
José P. Laurel takes the oath of office as President of the Philippines (Second Philippine Republic).
The last commerce raider ''hilfskreuzer Michel'', was sunk off Japan by United States submarine ''Tarpon''.
The RAF delivers a highly destructive airstrike on the German industrial and population center of Kassel.
HMS Eclipse (H08) is sunk by a mine.
Operation Goodtime: United States Marines land on Bougainville in the Solomon Islands.
In the early morning hours, American and Japanese ships fight the inconclusive Battle of Empress Augusta Bay off Bougainville.
British troops in Italy reach the Garigliano River.
After flying from Britain, 160 American bombers strike a hydro-electric power facility and heavy water factory in German-controlled Vemork, Norway.
A Japanese submarine sinks the surfaced U.S. submarine ''USS Corvina'' near Truk.
The Royal Air Force opens its bombing campaign against Berlin, with 440 planes causing only light damage and killing 131. The RAF loses 9 aircraft and 53 aviators.
Battle of Tarawa: United States Marines land on Tarawa and Makin atolls in the Gilbert Islands and take heavy fire from Japanese shore guns.
War in the Pacific: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt, British Prime Minister Winston Churchill, and ROC leader Chiang Kai-Shek meet at the Cairo Conference to discuss ways to defeat Japan.
Americans and Japanese fight the naval Battle of Cape St. George between Buka and New Ireland.

Tehran Conference: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt, British Prime Minister Winston Churchill and Soviet leader Joseph Stalin meet in Tehran to discuss war strategy (on November 30 they establish an agreement concerning a planned June 1944 invasion of Europe codenamed Operation Overlord).

The Great Depression officially ends in the United States: With unemployment figures falling fast due to WWII-related employment, U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt closes the Works Progress Administration
Bolivia declares war on Romania and Hungary.
Chiara Lubich starts the Focolare Movement in Trent, northern Italy, during WWII.
Free French General Jean de Lattre de Tassigny is appointed to command French Army B, part of the Sixth United States Army Group in North Africa.
The Battle of Monte Cassino begins.
Philippine Commonwealth troops enter the province of Ilocos Sur in Northern Luzon and attack Japanese forces.
Soviet troops start the offensive at Leningrad and Novgorod.
The 27th Polish Home Army Infantry Division is re-created, marking the start of Operation Tempest by the Polish Home Army.
Operation Shingle: The Allies begin the assault on Anzio, Italy. The U.S. Army 45th Infantry Division stands their ground at Anzio against violent assaults for 4 months.
The 2-year Siege of Leningrad is lifted.
The Battle of Cisterna takes place.
HMS Spartan (95)is sunk by a Henschel Hs 293 from a German aircraft off Anzio, western Italy.
United States troops invade Majuro, Marshall Islands.
American forces land on Kwajalein Atoll and other islands in the Japanese-held Marshall Islands.
United States troops land in the Marshall Islands.
United States troops capture the Marshall Islands.
In Anzio, Italian forces launch a counteroffensive.
Battle of Monte Cassino: The monastery atop Monte Cassino is destroyed by Allied bombing.
The Battle of Eniwetok Atoll begins it ends in an American victory on February 22.
The Chechens and Ingush are forcibly deported to Central Asia.
Battle of Los Negros and Operation Brewer: The Admiralty Islands are invaded by U.S. forces.
The Japanese launch an offensive in central and south China.
A train stalls inside a railway tunnel outside Salerno, Italy 521 choke to death.
The Order of Nakhimov and the Order of Ushakov are instituted in the USSR.
Soviet Army planes attack Narva, Estonia, destroying almost the entire old town.
Soviet Army planes attack Tallinn, Estonia.
In Britain the Education Act lifts the ban on women teachers marrying.
The Political Committee of National Liberation is created in Greece.
Battle of Monte Cassino: Allied aircraft bomb German-held monastery and stage an assault.
The National Council of the French Resistance approves the Resistance programme.
The Nazis execute almost 400 prisoners, Soviet citizens and anti-fascist Romanians at Rîbniţa.
German forces occupy Hungary in Operation Margarethe.

RAF Flight Sergeant Nicholas Alkemade's bomber is hit over Germany, and he has to bail out without a parachute from a height of over 4,000ampnbspmeters. Tree branches interrupt his fall and he lands safely on deep snow.
Members of the Italian Resistance attack Nazis marching in Via Rasella, killing 33.
: Ascq massacre members of the 2th SS Panzer Division Hitlerjugend shoot 85 people. When a train approaches  the Gare d'Ascq railyway station the railway line is blown apart.
An allied Surveillance aircraft photographs part of Auschwitz concentration camp.
749 American troops are killed in Exercise Tiger at Start Bay, Devon, England.
Mohandas Gandhi is released in India.

In the Ukrainian city of Sevastopol, Soviet troops completely drive out German forces, who had been ordered by Hitler to “fight to the last man.”ref name=quotReferenceAquotquotYear by Year 1944quot: History Channel International
Soviet troops finalize the liberation of the Crimea.
Six LSTs are accidentally destroyed and 163 men killed in Pearl Harbor's West Loch Disaster.
Destroyer escort ''England'' sinks the 6th Japanese submarine in two weeks.  This anti-submarine warfare performance remained unmatched through the twentieth century.
The BBC transmits a coded message (the first line of the poem quotChanson d'automnequot by Paul Verlaine) to the French Resistance, warning that the invasion of Europe is imminent.
The provisional French government is established.

Battle of Normandy: ''Operation Overlord'', commonly known as D-Day, commences with the landing of 155,000 Allied troops on the beaches of Normandy in France. The Allied soldiers quickly break through the Atlantic Wall and push inland, in the largest amphibious military operation in history. This operation helps liberate France from Germany, and also weakens the Nazi hold on Europe.
Soviet leader Joseph Stalin launches the Vyborg–Petrozavodsk Offensive against Finland, with the intent of defeating Finland before pushing for Berlin.
642 men, women and children are killed in the Oradour-sur-Glane Massacre in France.
Germany launches a V1 Flying Bomb attack on England.

Operation Bagration: A general attack by Soviet forces clears the German forces from Belarus, resulting in the destruction of German Army Group Centre, possibly the greatest defeat of the Wehrmacht during WWII.

The Battle of Tali-Ihantala (the largest battle ever in the Nordic countries) begins between Finnish and Soviet troops. Finland is able to resist the attack and thus manages to stay as an independent nation.
American troops enter Cherbourg.
At Camp Hood, Texas, future baseball star and 1st Lt. Jackie Robinson is arrested and later court-martialed for refusing to move to the back of a segregated U.S. Army bus. He is eventually acquitted.
British and Canadian forces capture Caen.
Soviet troops begin operations to occupy the Baltic countries.
Vilnius is occupied by USSR.
The first contingent of the Brazilian Expeditionary Force arrives in Italy.
Hideki Tojo resigns as Prime Minister of Japan due to numerous setbacks in the war effort.
Adolf Hitler survives an assassination attempt by Claus von Stauffenberg.
Operation Spring: One of the bloodiest days for Canadians during the war results in 1,550 casualties, including 450 killed.
A Messerschmitt Me 262 becomes the first jet fighter aircraft to have an operational victory.
The Warsaw Uprising begins.
Over 500 Japanese prisoners-of-war attempt a mass breakout from the Cowra POW Camp.
Operation Dragoon lands Allies in southern France. The U.S. Army 45th Infantry Division participates in its fourth assault landing at St. Maxime, spearheading the drive for the Belfort Gap.

Submarine ''Rasher'' sinks ''Teia Maru'', ''Eishin Maru'', ''Teiyu Maru'', and carrier Ship Japanese aircraft carrier Taiyō  2 from Japanese convoy HI71 in one of the most effective American quotwolfpackquot attacks of the war.
An insurrection starts in Paris.
Tsushima Maru, a Japanese unmarked passenger/cargo ship, is sunk by torpedoes launched by the submarine USS Bowfin off Akuseki-jima, killing 1,484 civilians including 767 schoolchildren.
Ion Antonescu, prime minister of Romania, is arrested and a new government established. Romania exits the war against Soviet Union, joining the Allies.
The Slovak National Uprising against the Axis powers begins.
In Bulgaria, the Bagryanov government resigns.
The Allies liberate Brussels.
The Soviets declare war on Bulgaria.
The Belgian government in exile returns to Brussels from London.
An insurrection breaks out in Sofia.
Northern and Southern France invasion forces link up near Dijon.
The Battle of Peleliu begins.
Operation Market Garden begins.
An armistice between Finland and the Soviet Union is signed, ending the Continuation War.
Jüri Uluots, prime minister in capacity of president of Estonia, escapes to Sweden 2 days later, Tallinn is taken by the Red Army.
The U.S. Army 45th Infantry Division takes the strongly defended city of Epinal before crossing the Moselle River and entering the western foothills of the Vosges.
Royal Canadian Air Force pilots shoot down the first German jet fighter over Holland.
The Battle of Debrecen starts on the Eastern Front (it lasts until October 29).
British Prime Minister Winston Churchill and Soviet Union Premier Joseph Stalin begin a 9-day conference in Moscow to discuss the future of Europe.
The Allies land in Athens.
Riga, the capital of Latvia, is taken by the Red Army.
German Field Marshal Erwin Rommel commits suicide rather than face execution for allegedly conspiring against Adolf Hitler.
The Volkssturm is founded on Hitler's orders.
Aachen, the first German city to fall, is captured by American troops.
The Naval Battle of Leyte Gulf in the Philippines begins (lasts until October 26).
Medal of Honor winning submarine ace Richard O'Kane becomes a prisoner of war when ''Tang'' is sunk in the Formosa Strait.
The Red Army liberates Kirkenes, the first town in Norway to be liberated.
Two supreme commanders of the Slovak National Uprising, Generals Ján Golian and Rudolf Viest, are captured, tortured and later executed by German forces.

Ammunition ship USS ''Mount Hood'' disintegrates from accidental detonation of 3800 tons of cargo in the Seeadler Harbor fleet anchorage at Manus Island. Twenty-two small boats are destroyed, 36 nearby ships damaged, 432 men are killed and 371 more are injured.

Submarine USS ''Archer-Fish'' sinks Japanese aircraft carrier ''Shinano''. ''Shinano'' is the largest carrier built to this date, and will remain through the twentieth century the largest ship sunk by a submarine.
Fighting breaks out between Communists and royalists in newly liberated Greece, eventually leading to a full-scale Greek Civil War.
December 13: British units attempt to take the hilltop town of Tossignano, but are repulsed.
German troops carry out the Malmedy massacre.
Brigadier General Anthony C. McAuliffe, commander of the U.S. forces defending Bastogne, refuses to accept demands for surrender by sending a one-word reply, quotNuts!quot, to the German command.
The Bulge reaches its deepest point at Celles.

Troopship ''Leopoldville'' is sunk in the English Channel by German submarine U-486.  The ship was carrying reinforcements to the battle of the bulge and 763 soldiers of the 66th Infantry Division (United States) drown.
American troops repulse German forces at Bastogne.
Hungary declares war on Nazi Germany.
Battle of Leyte: Tens of thousands of Imperial Japanese Army soldiers are killed in action, in a significant Filipino and Allied military victory.
The 1944 Summer Olympics, scheduled for London (together with the February Winter Olympics scheduled for Cortina d'Ampezzo in Italy), are suspended due to WWII.
The Soviet Union begins the Vistula-Oder Offensive in Eastern Europe against the Germans.
A day after beginning the Vistula-Oder Offensive, the Soviets launch the East Prussian Offensive to eliminate German forces in East Prussia.
A Soviet patrol arrests Raoul Wallenberg in Hungary.
The Soviet Union occupies Warsaw, Poland.
Hungary drops out of WWII, agreeing to an armistice with the Allies.
Infantry action at Holtzwihr, France, for which Audie Murphy is awarded the Medal of Honor.
Supplies begin to reach China over the newly reopened Burma Road.
February 11: President Franklin D. Roosevelt, Prime Minister of the United Kingdom Winston Churchill and Soviet leader Joseph Stalin hold the Yalta Conference.

link.text_in_event: Prime Minister of the United Kingdom

description: General Douglas MacArthur returns to Manila.

ampquotBlack Fridayampquot: A force of Allied Bristol Beaufighter aircraft suffers heavy casualties in an unsuccessful attack on German destroyer ''Z33'' and escorting vessels sheltering in Førde Fjord, Norway.
The ''SS General von Steuben'' is sunk by the Soviet submarine S-13.
Battle of Iwo Jima: About 30,000 United States Marines land on Iwo Jima.
American troops seize the bridge over the Rhine River at Remagen, Germany and begin to cross.
March 10: American B-29 bombers attack Tokyo, Japan with incendiary bombs the city is fire-bombed, killing 100,000 citizens.
The Battle of Iwo Jima unofficially ends, with pockets of guerrilla resistance persisting until the official conclusion of the battle.
Kobe, Japan is fire-bombed by 331 B-29 bombers, killing over 8,000 people.
1,250 American bombers attack Berlin.
British troops liberate Mandalay, Burma.
Operation Varsity: Two airborne divisions capture bridges across the Rhine River to aid the Allied advance.
The Battle of Iwo Jima officially ends, with the destruction of the remaining areas of Japansese resistance.
Battle of Okinawa: The U.S. 10th Army lands on Okinawa.
American troops liberate their first Nazi concentration camp, Ohrdruf death camp in Germany.
Sarajevo is liberated from the Nazi Germany and Nazi Croatia (German puppet state) by the Yugoslav Partisans.
The Battle of Königsberg, in East Prussia, ends.
The Canadian First Army assumes military control of the Netherlands where German forces are trapped in the Atlantic wall fortifications along the coastline.
April 15: The Canadian First Army reaches the coast in northern Holland and captures Arnhem.
The ''Goya'' is sunk by the ''Soviet submarine L-3''.
April 16: The Canadians take Harlingen,  and occupies Leeuwarden and Groningen
April 16: Battle of Berlin begins.
Elbe Day: United States and Soviet troops link up at the Elbe River, cutting Germany in two.
Last major strategic bombing raid by RAF Bomber Command, the destruction of the oil refinery at Tønsberg in southern Norway by 107 Avro Lancasters.
Battle of Bautzen: The last quotsuccessfulquot German panzer-offensive in Bautzen ends with the city recaptured.
April 26: The Nazis surrender to the British/Canadian front who now control the Swiss border from Basle to Lake Constance.

A Japanese balloon bomb kills five children and a woman, Elsie Mitchell, near Bly, Oregon, when it explodes as they drag it from the woods. They are the only people killed by an enemy attack on the American mainland during WWII.
Axis Sally delivers her last propaganda broadcast to Allied troops (the first was on December 11, 1941).
General Alfred Jodl signs unconditional surrender terms at Reims, France, ending Germany's participation in the war. The document takes effect the next day.

V-E Day (Victory in Europe, as Nazi Germany surrenders) commemorates the end of WWII in Europe, with the final surrender being to the Soviets in Berlin, attended by representatives of the Western Powers.
15: Battle of Poljana: The last battle of the War in Europe is fought at Poljana near Slovenj Gradec, Slovenia.
The Battle of Okinawa ends.
A victory parade is held in Red Square in Moscow.
Germany is divided between the Allied occupation forces.
The Philippines are declared liberated.
Harry S. Truman is informed that Japan will talk peace if it can retain the reign of the Emperor.ref name=quotnuclearfiles1940quot/
A train collision near Munich, Germany kills 102 war prisoners.
President Harry S. Truman approves the order for atomic bombs to be used against Japan.ref name=quotnuclearfiles1940quot/
French marshal Philippe Pétain, who headed the Vichy government during WWII, goes on trial for treason.
Japan ambiguously rejects the Potsdam Declaration.ref name=quotnuclearfiles1940quot/

The heavy cruiser USS ''Indianapolis'' is hit and sunk by torpedoes from the ''Japanese submarine I-58'' in the Philippine Sea. Some 900 survivors jump into the sea and are adrift for up to four days. Nearly 600 die before help arrives. Captain Charles B. McVay III of the cruiser is later court-martialed and convicted.
Potsdam Conference: At Potsdam, the three main Allied leaders hold their final summit of the war.
Atomic bombing of Hiroshima: A United States B-29 Superfortress, the Enola Gay, drops an atomic bomb, codenamed quotLittle Boyquot, on Hiroshima, Japan, at 8:15 a.m. (local time).
Japan offers to surrender to the Allies, quotprovided this does not prejudice the sovereignty of the Emperorquot.
The Allies reply to the Japanese surrender offer by saying that Emperor Hirohito will be subject to the authority of the Supreme Commander of the Allied Forces.

link.text_in_event: Supreme Commander of the Allied Forces

description: Emperor Hirohito accepts the terms of the Potsdam Declaration.

Emperor Hirohito announces Japan's surrender on the radio. The United States calls this day V-J Day (Victory in Japan). This ends the period of Japanese expansionism and begins the period of Occupied Japan.
Korea gains independence following Japan's surrender.
Allied troops arrest German field marshal Walther von Brauchitsch.

WWII ends: The final official surrender of Japan is accepted by the Supreme Allied Commander, General Douglas MacArthur, and Fleet Admiral Chester Nimitz for the United States, and delegates from Australia, New Zealand, the United Kingdom, The Netherlands, China, and others from a Japanese delegation led by Mamoru Shigemitsu, on board the American battleship USS ''Missouri'' in Tokyo Bay.
Japanese forces surrender on Wake Island after hearing word of their country's surrender.
Hideki Tōjō, Japanese prime minister during most of WWII, attempts suicide to avoid facing a war crimes tribunal.
Pierre Laval, the former premier of Vichy France, is shot to death by a firing squad for treason against France.
The Nuremberg Trials begin: Trials against 24 Nazi war criminals of WWII start at the Nuremberg Palace of Justice.
